overview_of_class:
This seminar on American foreign policy will explore the American role in the world from 1961 to the present. During the first two sessions, attention will be focused on the transition from Bush's interventionist foreign policy, to Obama's reticent foreign policy to Trumps AMERICA FIRST foreign policy. This will include the Bush National Security Doctrine, the American interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan and Libya; the impact of September 11, 2001 and terrorism on the Bush, Obama and Trump policies; and to the Trump and Obama responses to the ISIS threat in Syria and Iraq. Sessions will address the Cold War context of American foreign policy in the early 1960's and the US-Soviet confrontation over Berlin and Cuba; the American involvement in Vietnam and its impact; the period of détente followed by the resurgence of American power in the 1980's; the waning and ending of the Cold War, the emergence and spread of globalization during the last three decades; and of the rising influence of China and India on the future of American hegemony; and, he Iran nuclear agreement and the escalation of the North Korean nuclear threat at the beginning of the Trump administration.

The course will address not only geopolitical issues, but also decision-making and the interaction between public opinion and foreign policy. Some background in American foreign policy, international relations or political science is desirable for students signing up for this seminar.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
